intro: Lupinus werdermannianus, commonly known as the Werdermann's lupine, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its erect growth habit and spiny stems. The plant produces clusters of blue to purple pea-shaped flowers, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are compound, consisting of several small, oval-shaped leaflets. Lupinus werdermannianus is adapted to rocky and arid environments, often found in coastal regions and mountainous areas.
